measured_by: Cumulative Prospect Theory (CPT) with simulated and empirical gambles
justification: The paper uses CPT models with various parameters to simulate and analyze differences between description-based decisions (DBDs) and experience-based decisions (EBDs), showcasing how asymmetric learning can explain observed gaps in probability weighting and risk preferences across tasks.

measured_by: Reinforcement Learning and Cumulative Prospect Theory hybrid model (RL-CPT)
justification: The RL-CPT model incorporates separate learning rates for positive and negative prediction errors to better capture behavioral differences across DBDs and EBDs, outperforming standard CPT models in empirical model comparisons.

The CPT risk sensitivity parameter α is shown to be consistently underestimated for experience-based decisions relative to description-based decisions when using traditional CPT modeling with asymmetric learning rates.

The CPT loss aversion parameter λ is generally underestimated for experiencer based decisions, particularly for non-reduced gamble sets, aligning with the asymmetric learning hypothesis proposed in the study.

Probability weighting parameter γ showed biases in EBDs relative to DBDs based on asymmetric learning rates and sample size, with RL-CPT providing a more accurate representation of true values compared to traditional CPT.
